title: Manufacturing Activity Softens in September — Richmond Fed
text:
By Dave Sebastian

Manufacturing activity across mid-Atlantic states softened in September, according to a report from the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, as indexes for shipments and the volume of new orders fell.

The Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond said the composite manufacturing index fell to negative 9 in September from 1 in August. The index had rebounded in August from July's negative 12. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal expected a reading of zero for the September period.

Positive readings signal expansion, while negative readings indicate contraction.

Firms reported a decrease in backlog of orders, the index for which dropped to negative 11 from negative 9 in August, as well as weakening local business conditions but were optimistic of improvement in coming months, according to the report. The measure of local business conditions slid to negative -15 from -3 in August.

The volume of new orders declined to negative 14 in September from 2 in August. Manufacturing shipments fell to negative 14 in September from 5 in August. Finished goods inventories rose to 13 in September from 10 in August, while raw materials inventories rose to 24 from 21.

Respondents said wages continued to grow in September and employment slightly increased in the manufacturing sector during the month. However, respondents said they struggled to find workers with the right skills and that they expect to continue struggling to find them in the next six months, despite the respondents' expectations of continued wage and employment growth.

The indicator for the average workweek declined from 4 in August to negative 10, a nine-year low, according to the report.

The Richmond Fed district includes Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, the District of Columbia, Maryland and the bulk of West Virginia.
